feed.title: NewsTracker: google
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Google wins dismissal of Android privacy lawsuit
Google wins dismissal of Android privacy lawsuit
entry.summary:
Google did not immediately respond to a similar request.

Grewal said it would unfairly prejudice Google to let the plaintiffs amend their lawsuit again.

The case is In re: Google Inc Privacy Policy Litigation, U.S. District Court, Northern District of California, No.

entry.title: Google unveils buying button in mobile shopping ads
entry.summary:
The feature, called "Purchases on Google," completes sales using financial information that already has been stored with Google.

Participating merchants can still gather information about customers using Google's buying button.

About a dozen retailers are initially using Google's buying button.

entry.title: Google unveils buying button in mobile shopping ads
entry.summary: Google is introducing a way for shoppers browsing on their smartphones to buy merchandise by tapping on a button included in the ads appearing in its search results.

entry.title: Google unveils buying button in mobile shopping ads
Google Unveils 'Buy' Button, Host of New Shopping Features
entry.summary: The eagerly awaited "buy" feature, which Google said it was testing with a few retailers, uses saved payment credentials from the user s Google Account for transactions.

entry.title: Google unveils 'buy' button, new shopping features
entry.summary:
Google on Wednesday unveiled a new feature called "Purchases on Google," which allows shopper to buy items directly from mobile search ads.

Google also said its Google Now service is offering location-based information, including on discounts on items and the working hours of stores a user is close to.

entry.title: Google Photos uploads pics even after you uninstall
entry.summary: (Go to Google Settings > Google Photo Backup.)

entry.title: Google tests driverless cars in Austin _ with safety drivers
entry.summary: Google did not say exactly where the driverless cars would be tested.

entry.title: Google testing self-driving prototype cars in Texas
entry.summary:
Google and other automotive manufacturers and suppliers have said the technology to build self-driving cars should be ready by 2020.

Google executives have said the company does not want to build its own self-driving cars, but would prefer to find a development and production partner.

entry.title: Google Incâ€™s Waze mapping company to launch carpooling pilot program in Israel
entry.summary: Google bought Israel-based Waze, which uses satellite signals from members' smartphones to offer real-time traffic information, for about US$1 billion two years ago.

entry.title: Google Tests Carpooling Service for Commuters in Israel
Google's new self-driving cars cruising Silicon Valley roads
entry.summary:
California's Department of Motor Vehicles have given Google permission to send up to 25 of its latest self-driving cars on neighborhood roads.

Google had installed its robotic driving technology in Lexus sports utility vehicles during the first few years of testing before developing the smaller prototype.

The debut of the pod-like car will help Google get a better understanding on how well its technology works around other vehicles steered by people.

Google blamed the collisions on other vehicles in every instance except one when the company says one of its own employees was steering.

entry.title: Nazi concentration camps found in mobile game
entry.summary:
BERLIN -- A Google subsidiary has apologized for making Nazi concentration camps part of a mobile role-playing game.

Gabriele Hammermann, director of the memorial site at Dachau, told the dpa news agency that Google's actions were a humiliation for victims and relatives of the Nazi camps.

entry.title: Google apologizes for app tagging black people as 'gorillas'
entry.summary:
NEW YORK -- Google is apologizing after reports surfaced that an automatic image-recognition feature in its Photos application was identifying images of some black people as "gorillas."

A New York man posted a picture of himself and a female friend on Twitter earlier this week, showing that the Google image software had tagged both of them as "gorillas," which is sometimes used as a racial slur.

entry.title: Google apologizes after report of photo app tagging black people as 'gorillas'
entry.summary: Google says it's "appalled and genuinely sorry" for what happened with the image-recognition feature.

entry.title: Google's new app blunders by calling black people 'gorillas'
entry.summary: The images showed the recently released Google Photos app had sorted a picture of two black people into a category labeled as "gorillas."

entry.title: Google 'genuinely sorry' after report photo app tagged black people 'gorillas'
entry.summary: The "Google" logo is pictured.

entry.title: Google Photo App Labels Black Couple 'Gorillas'
Google to remove revenge porn from its search results
entry.summary:
That libertarian approach helped establish Google as the world's most dominant search engine, processing roughly two-thirds of all online requests for information.

The new rules announced Friday will allow people whose naked pictures have been posted on a website without their permission to ask Google to prevent links to the image from appearing in its search results.

entry.title: Google app to warn drivers about railroad crossings
entry.summary: Google has agreed to add audio and visual alerts in its navigation app to warn drivers about railroad crossings.

entry.title: Google denied appeal in Oracle software fight
entry.summary: A Google representative did not immediately comment on the court's decision, and an Oracle spokeswoman could not immediately be reached.

entry.title: Google denied appeal in Oracle software fight
entry.summary: WASHINGTON - The U.S. Supreme Court on Monday sided with Oracle Corp. and declined to hear Google Inc.'s appeal in a major software copyright case that has been closely followed by the technology industry.

entry.title: Justices won't hear Google appeal in dispute with Oracle
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - The Supreme Court is staying out of a long-running legal battle between technology giants Oracle and Google over copyright protection for a computer program that powers most of the world's smartphones and computer tablets.

entry.title: What does Google have in store for the future?
entry.summary:
Did you know that Google has been known to rent goats to "mow" its grass at the Googleplex complex in Mountain View, Calif.?

Google lost out on buying the live-streaming site Twitch last year.

Of course, Google isn't just all about streaming and websites.

entry.title: What does Google have in store for the future?
entry.summary: Rather than just cry about what went wrong and how they lost out on the deal, Google has been hard at work creating its own "Twitch killer."

entry.title: Google's new self-driving cars cruising Silicon Valley roads
entry.summary: This marks the first time that the pod-like, two seat vehicles have been allowed on public roads since Google unveiled the next generation of its self-driving fleet more than a year ago.

entry.title: Google's New Self-Driving Cars Cruising Silicon Valley Roads
entry.summary: The latest models of Google's self-driving cars are now cruising the streets near the Internet company's Silicon Valley headquarters in a test of how they work around other vehicles driven by people.

entry.title: Google makes a big bet on... Alabama?
entry.summary: Google has emphasized using clean energy to power the centers.

entry.title: Virtually climb El Capitan with Google's first vertical Street View
entry.summary:
Lynn Hill is one of the climbers featured in Google's vertical Street View of El Capitan in Yosemite National Park.

Google Maps has announced its first vertical Street View, giving people the opportunity to virtually climb El Capitan in Yosemite National Park.

entry.title: Google announces 'revenge porn' crackdown
entry.summary:
Google says it is taking steps to remove sexually explicit images of people posted without their consent - known as "revenge porn" - from their search results.

Mr Singhal said Google would "honour requests from people to remove nude or sexually explicit images shared without their consent from Google search results".

entry.title: Google cracks down on 'revenge porn' under new nudity policy
entry.summary: This isn't the first time Google has excised sensitive content from its search index.

entry.title: Google cracks down on 'revenge porn' under new nudity policy
Google to censor revenge porn
entry.summary:
SAN FRANCISCO -- Google plans to censor unauthorized nude photos from its influential Internet search engine in a policy change aimed at cracking down on a malicious practice known as "revenge porn."

Google traditionally has resisted efforts to erase online content from its Internet search engine, maintaining that its judgments about information and images should be limited to how relevant the material is to each person's query.

entry.title: Google to censor revenge porn
entry.summary:
Google's stand against revenge porn won't necessarily purge it from the Internet because it has no authority to order other sites to remove offensive or even illegal content.

But Google is hoping revenge porn will prove less mortifying to its intended victims by making it more difficult to find.
